description:
Talpa europaea, commonly known as the European mole, is a small, fossorial mammal that belongs to the family Talpidae. It is widely distributed throughout Europe, from the United Kingdom and Scandinavia to the Iberian Peninsula and eastern Europe.

The European mole is a highly specialized subterranean creature, adapted to a life spent mostly underground. It has a cylindrical, stocky body with a short, velvety fur that can range in color from black to brown or even gray. Its front limbs are modified into powerful, shovel-like hands with enlarged claws, which it uses to dig extensive tunnel systems in search of food, primarily earthworms and other invertebrates.

The European mole is a solitary and territorial animal, and it is known for its unique adaptations that enable it to thrive in its underground environment. Its small, beady eyes and lack of external ears are adaptations to its subterranean lifestyle, while its sensitive touch receptors and well-developed sense of smell help it navigate and locate prey within its burrow system.

This species plays an important role in the ecosystem, as its burrowing activities contribute to soil aeration and nutrient cycling, while also providing food and habitat for other organisms. The European mole is classified as a species of Least Concern by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), but it faces threats from habitat loss, chemical pollution, and persecution by humans due to the damage it can cause to agricultural land.
